newsitem.title: SWEDEN: Swedish film director Widerberg dies aged 66.
newsitem.headline: Swedish film director Widerberg dies aged 66.

text.p: Swedish film director and writer Bo Widerberg, known for sensuous soft focus shots and socially critical work, died on Wednesday, his family said. He was 66.
His last film, All Things Fair, was nominated for an Oscar last year.

Born on June 8, 1930 in Malmo, Sweden, of a modest family background, Widerberg left school early and worked at odd jobs before pursuing writing. He went on to write novels, short stories and a radio play.
The young director made a name for himself with his 1963 black-and-white film Raven's End about an aspiring writer living with his working class parents in 1930s Sweden.

He won international acclaim with his 1967 film, Elvira Madigan, a tragic romance set in 19th-century Sweden between a married nobleman and a tightrope walker who elope to spend a last summer together before committing suicide.

His last film, which was nominated for the best foreign movie Oscar, was set in Sweden in 1943 and about a 15-year-old boy who has a love affair with his teacher. Johan Widerberg, the director's son, played the role of the student.
His other films include The Pram, Love 65, Adalen 31, The Ballad of Joe Hill, Stubby, The Man on the Roof, The Man from Mallorca and The Serpent's Way.
He is survived by his four children.
